title: MAPPING EMERGING GENDER ARTIVISM IN THE MEDITERRANEAN ARAB PUBLIC SPACE
descriptions:
**Abstract:**

This grant proposal outlines the objectives of MEGAMAPS, a pioneering research project that seeks to investigate and document Artivism for gender equality in the Mediterranean Arab public space post-2011 uprisings. The project's innovative interdisciplinary approach combines History, Social Movements Theory, Gender Studies, Visual Arts, and Digital Humanities to examine the phenomena in Jordan, Lebanon, Morocco, and Tunisia. MEGAMAPS aims to enrich global academic knowledge of the Arab region by crafting a unique 'history from below', examining the interplay between gender, public aesthetic dissent, and social transformation.

Central to the project is the development of an open-access, participative digital platform that will serve as the first research tool of its kind focusing on Artivism, gender, and social change in the Arab region. This platform will document, organize, and interlink a living corpus of sources, including visual and performative arts, oral interviews, and innovative cartographic and graphic tools, making it widely accessible to scholars, practitioners, and the public. It will challenge traditional approaches to History and Social Movements Theory regarding the Arab world and make the collected data FAIRly accessible.

MEGAMAPS will also engage in dissemination activities, fostering a transnational network of artists, researchers, policymakers, and civil society stakeholders. These activities aim to facilitate the exchange of best practices in the realm of gender equality, arts, and democratic governance. The project intends to counteract the victimization narrative surrounding women and sexual minorities in the Arab region by promoting an agency paradigm. Furthermore, it aspires to dismantle orientalist and Islamophobic attitudes within Western public opinion, offering a new perspective on the region's sociopolitical dynamics through the lens of grassroots artistic movements.
